description: Seed data for team architecture decisions and project context (ADR-style)
usage: Copy to your MEMORY_PATH location: cp examples/scenarios/team-decisions.json .copilot-memory.json

records.text: ADR-001: Monorepo structure using Turborepo. Context: multiple packages need to share code. Decision: single repo with packages/ directory. Consequences: shared tooling, atomic commits, but larger repo size.

ADR-002: Event-driven architecture for order processing. Context: need async processing and audit trail. Decision: publish domain events to Kafka. Consequences: eventual consistency, but full traceability.
ADR-003: CQRS for order queries. Context: complex reporting needs. Decision: separate read models optimized for queries. Consequences: data duplication, but better read performance.
Tech stack decided: Node.js 20 LTS, TypeScript 5.3, React 18, Next.js 14 (App Router)
Hosting on AWS: ECS Fargate for services, RDS for PostgreSQL, ElastiCache for Redis, S3 for assets
Team: 4 devs (2 senior, 2 mid), 1 QA, 1 PM. Timezone: PST. Standup: 9am daily.
Sprint cadence: 2 weeks. Planning Monday, retro every other Friday. Jira for tracking.
CI/CD: GitHub Actions. PRs require 1 approval + passing tests. Main branch auto-deploys to staging.
Production deploys: manual trigger after QA sign-off. Blue-green deployment via AWS.
Security review required for: auth changes, payment handling, PII access, external API integrations
Secrets management: AWS Secrets Manager for production, .env.local for dev (gitignored)
Legacy migration: old system uses Oracle DB + Java Spring. Migrating incrementally via strangler fig pattern.
Migration phase 1 complete: user service migrated. Phase 2 in progress: order service. Phase 3 pending: payment.
Performance SLOs: p99 latency < 200ms for API, p99 < 500ms for reports. Alert if exceeded for 5min.
Lesson learned: Redis connection pool exhaustion caused outage. Now use connection pooling with max 50 connections per service.
